qas.question: Until the mid 1900s most elevators lacked what?

answers.text: automatic positioning of the floor on which the cab would stop

qas.question: Many earlier built  freight elevators were controlled by what?

answers.text: switches operated by pulling on adjacent ropes

qas.question: How were most elevators built before 1939 powered?

answers.text: by elevator operators using a rheostat connected to the motor

qas.question: A rheostat is the size and shape of what?

answers.text: upright or sideways on the cab wall

context: In the first half of the twentieth century, almost all elevators had no <a0_0>automatic positioning of the floor on which the cab would stop<a0_0/>. Some of the older freight elevators were controlled by <a1_0>switches operated by pulling on adjacent ropes<a1_0/>. In general, most elevators before WWII were manually controlled <a2_0>by elevator operators using a rheostat connected to the motor<a2_0/>. This rheostat (see picture) was enclosed within a cylindrical container about the size and shape of <a3_0>a cake<a3_0/>. This was mounted <a4_0>upright or sideways on the cab wall<a4_0/> and operated via a projecting handle, which was able to slide around the top half of the cylinder.
